definition:
The *adjugate*, ${{\operatorname{adj}}(A)}$, of an $n\times n$ matrix
$A$, is the $n\times n$ matrix $$\label{eq:def1}
  {{\operatorname{adj}}(A)}_{ij} = (-1)^{i+j}\, M_{\!ji}(A)$$ where
$M_{\!ji}(A)$ is the indicated minor of $A$ (the determinant obtained by
deleting row $j$ and column $i$ from $A$). The adjugate is also known as
the *classical adjoint*, to distinguish it from the which denotes the
conjugate transpose operation.

An equivalent characterization of the adjugate is the following:
$$\label{eq:def2}
  {{\operatorname{adj}}(A)}A = \det(A) I.$$ The equivalence of and
follows easily from the of the determinant. Thus, the adjugate operation
is closely related to the matrix inverse. Indeed, if $A$ is invertible,
the adjugate can be defined as
$${{\operatorname{adj}}(A)}= \det(A)A^{-1}$$

Yet another definition of the adjugate is the following:
$$\begin{aligned}
  \label{eq:def3}
  {{\operatorname{adj}}(A)}= p_{n-1}(A) I &- p_{n-2}(A) A + p_{n-3}(A) A^2 - \cdots \\ \nonumber
  & +  (-1)^{n-2}p_1(A) A^{n-2} + (-1)^{n-1}A^{n-1},\end{aligned}$$
where $p_1(A)=\operatorname{tr}(A), p_2(A),\ldots, p_n(A) = \det(A)$ are
the elementary invariant polynomials of $A$. The latter arise as
coefficients in the characteristic polynomial $p(t)$ of $A$, namely
$$p(t) = \det(t I - A) = t^n - p_1(A) t^{n-1} + \cdots + (-1)^n p_n(A).$$
The equivalence of and follows from the Cayley-Hamilton theorem. The
latter states that $p(A)=0$, which in turn implies that
$$A ( A^{n-1} - p_1(A) A^{n-2} + \cdots + (-1)^{n-1} p_{n-1}(A) ) =
 (-1)^{n-1} \det(A) I$$

The adjugate operation enjoys a number of notable properties:
$$\begin{aligned}
  &{\operatorname{adj}}(AB) ={\operatorname{adj}}(B){\operatorname{adj}}(A),\\
  &{\operatorname{adj}}(A^t) = {{\operatorname{adj}}(A)}^t,\\
  &\det({{\operatorname{adj}}(A)}) = \det(A)^{n-1}.\end{aligned}$$
